awd_titl_txt: Study on Localized Exponential Time Differencing Methods for Evolution Partial Differential Equations
awd_abstract_narration:
Many important physical phenomena are modeled by semilinear or fully nonlinear evolution partial differential equations. The overall goal of the project is to enhance the efficiency and scalability of exponential integrator-based methods for solving these equations by designing and analyzing highly scalable localized exponential time differencing methods and to apply them to numerically simulate and investigate a wide range of related application problems in science and engineering. The proposed work is of practical interest with significant influences as the developed methods are highly scalable on modern supercomputer systems, and can serve as an efficient, accurate and stable computational tool for simulations of these stiff problems. Direct and transformative innovations resulting from the project will greatly improve modeling and computational capabilities for many fields, such as design of new materials and oil recovery from fractured oil reservoirs. In addition, this project will also offer a unique educational opportunity for graduate students with interests in computational and applied mathematics by having them participate in an interdisciplinary research environment.

Direct parallelization of global exponential time differencing methods is often very hard to be scalable on massively distributed systems due to the intensive data communications needed by fast Fourier transform or by Krylov subspace-based calculations for products of matrix exponentials and vectors. On the other hand, domain decomposition approaches have been well established for many classic time integration methods, but not enough attention and work have been devoted to exponential integrators. This project involves a thorough study on the development and analysis of iterative and noniterative localized exponential time differencing methods based on domain decomposition, with a family of time-dependent scalar diffusion equations as the prototype problem. The PI will also apply the developed methods to study some phase field models for multi-component and multi-phase systems arising from materials science and petroleum engineering. This project would offer new insights through numerical investigations to the understanding of the macroscopic properties and reliability of alloys and the physical phenomena (such as liquid droplets, gas bubbles, and capillary pressure) of hydrocarbon fluids.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many important physical phenomena in nature are modeled by semilinear or nonlinear evolutional partial differential equations. Some typical examples include the phase transition in alloys, the shape transformation of vesicle membranes, the epitaxy growth for thin film deposition, the atomic crystals formulation, the hydrocarbon fluids, the superconductivity, and the propagation of the light in nonlinear optical fibers. With the fast development of computing technology, exponential integrator methods have been popularly used for time integration of these stiff evolution equations due to their excellent numerical accuracy and stability, and many significant progresses have been achieved in recent years. For example, the extreme-scale parallel phase field simulations of three-dimensional coarsening dynamics based on the exponential time differencing schemes and domain decomposition won a finalist of 2016 Gordon-Bell Prize in high-performance computing.

 

The main goal of this project is to perform a thorough study of highly efficient and scalable exponential integrator methods for solving evolutional partial differential equations arising from diverse science and engineering fields. During the three-year period of the project, we designed and analyzed the localized exponential time differencing algorithms for the diffusion equations, the Allen-Cahn type equations, and the rotating shallow water equations. This is of practical interest with significant influences as the developed methods are highly suitable for implementation and simulation on modern supercomputer systems. We also built an abstract framework and analysis techniques for studying maximum bound principles and related numerical schemes of a wide class of semilinear parabolic partial differential equations. By following this framework, a family of novel exponential integrator methods have been developed for some classic phase field models, which can preserve in the discrete sense the maximum bound principles and/or some other important physical properties of the system such as the energy dissipation laws and the mass conservation law. To facilitate the applications, these state-of-art numerical algorithms produced from the project also have been applied to many other disciplines such as materials science, geoscience and fluids dynamics. The results have enhanced interdisciplinary researches and provided new insights through numerical investigations to the understanding of physical phenomena in these fields.

 

This project has produced about nineteen research papers which have been published in first-tier academic journals and conference proceedings, including the very influential SIAM Review in the field of computational science and engineering. The results of this project have been presented in more than thirty professional conference and seminar/colloquium presentations. This award partially supported six PhD students through graduate research assistantships in regular academical semesters and summer months at the University of South Carolina, and particularly two of them are females who are under-represented in the community. The project has been an excellent vehicle for training graduate students with a broad knowledge base in the interdisciplinary research and the impacts are substantial in terms of both education and research.
